A Data details Throughout, we restrict our sample by dropping workers who are younger than 17 years old, do not report positive paid hours worked, are self-employed, or are in the military.

MORG. We use the MORG CPS to form a sampleÃÂ¢Ãâ¬Ãâfor each worker groupÃÂ¢Ãâ¬Ãâof hours worked and income. We use the ÃÂ¢Ãâ¬ÃÅhour wage sampleÃÂ¢Ãâ¬ÃÂ from Acemoglu and Autor (2011). Hourly wages are equal to the reported hourly earnings for those paid by the hour and the usual weekly earnings divided by hours worked last week for non-hourly workers. Top-coded earnings observations are multiplied by 1.5. Workers earning below $1.675/hour in 1982 dollars are dropped, as are workers whose hourly wages exceed 1/35th the top-coded value of weekly earnings (i.e., workers paid by the hour whose wages are sufficiently high so that their weekly income would be top-coded if they worked at least 35 hours and were not paid by the hour). Allocated earnings observations are excluded in all years. Our measure of labor composition, Lt (ÃÅ½ÃÂ»), is hours worked within each labor group ÃÅ½ÃÂ» (weighted by sample weights).
